title: The Struggles of the EV Revolution: Audi's Brussels Factory
description: In this episode, we explore why Audi's Brussels plant is facing closure, the challenges of making electric vehicles affordable, and how automakers' strategies might be missing the mark.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'life is artificial', where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we have an interesting and somewhat sobering story about the state of the electric vehicle market in Europe. Volkswagen, a giant in the auto industry, is facing some tough decisions that are indicative of the broader struggles for automakers and the EV transition. We're diving into the recent news about Volkswagen-owned Audi, and the potential closure of a major production plant in Brussels—something that's happening for the first time in history.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So what's happening here? Essentially, Audi has announced plans to stop production on its Q8 E-Tron, a high-end electric SUV that just isn't selling well enough. The Brussels factory, which makes this model, is now at risk of being shut down entirely. It’s a decision that’s drawn quite a bit of controversy, including huge protests from the plant workers and unions in Belgium. But what led to this situation? Why is this particular electric vehicle struggling?

script.speaker: Host
script.text: It seems there are a few reasons. The Q8 E-Tron is an expensive vehicle, priced around €80,000—a price tag that puts it out of reach for the average consumer in Europe. Sales have been disappointing, and the plant, which has a capacity to produce 120,000 vehicles, only managed to hit a peak of 47,900 cars in 2022, dropping further last year and continuing to decline this year. It's clear that the model simply isn't resonating with enough buyers, and there’s a growing sense that automakers might have missed the mark by focusing too much on luxury EVs.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, this isn't just about one plant in Brussels or even one car model. It's emblematic of a larger trend that’s happening across the industry. Consumers do want electric cars, but they want affordable electric cars—cars that make the switch from internal combustion engines realistic for their budgets. What we’ve been seeing instead is that many European carmakers, including Volkswagen, have been focusing on large SUVs with hefty price tags. And that’s creating a major barrier to entry for average consumers.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: I find it fascinating—and somewhat worrying—that this strategy has persisted even though the data shows only a small percentage of the vehicles being sold are EVs. Just think about it: In the first eight months of this year, only about 12.6% of cars sold in the EU were electric. It's clear that the gap between what automakers are producing and what consumers can afford is widening.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So what does this mean for the workers at the Brussels plant? Well, there are about 3,000 people employed there, and the likelihood of losing those jobs is quite high. Unions have been vocal, arguing that VW and Audi aren't doing enough to explore alternatives. According to union leaders, it seems as if the company just wants to pull out quickly without giving serious consideration to any proposed solutions.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And it’s not just Brussels. Volkswagen is also looking at its German factories, and for the first time, the company is even considering closing a plant on its home turf in Germany due to overproduction issues. It really points to a fundamental miscalculation of demand, and a misalignment of product strategy in this period of transition to electric vehicles.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: There’s a lot at stake here, not just for the companies involved, but for the broader shift to electric mobility in Europe. With unions warning of more strikes and calling for increased public funding, the situation raises important questions about how governments, manufacturers, and even us as consumers can make the EV revolution a reality—and not just for the wealthy.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: It’s a complicated issue, but one that’s critical to understand. So as we see these protests unfold in Brussels and watch what happens with Audi and VW, it’s a reminder that the transition to electric isn’t just about making new cars. It's about making the right kind of cars that people can actually buy. The EV future is not just about technology; it's also about affordability, accessibility, and understanding the needs of the real market.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That’s it for today’s episode. I’d love to hear your thoughts on this story. Are automakers doing enough to make electric vehicles accessible? Or is there a fundamental flaw in their strategy? You can share your views on our social channels, and don’t forget to subscribe for more discussions on technology, innovation, and the future. Until next time, this is 'life is artificial', and I’m your host signing off.
